TopicTitle: Is the unit of force "N" a Greek character?

Articles.Content:
As is shown in title, is the character of unit "Newton" the 13th Greek character "ÃŽÂ" instead of the English "N"?

How do western students pronounce this?

It's just the modern day letter N.

New in Newton is pronounced exactly the same as the word "new".

The ton is pronounced the same as 'ten' in heighten, so much softer than the word "ten".
i've always known it to be "N" the english letter - as the word is 1 Newton this made sense to me. similar to a meter being "m"
It's an N like in Newton, not a capital nu
Nu should have been one of the metric prefix symbols. Then I could claim that Newton is a unit of mass. ÃŽÂ½T.
